head.title: Extinction transition in bacterial colonies under forced convection

article.h1: Extinction transition in bacterial colonies under forced convection

div.p: We report the spatio-temporal response of Bacillus subtilis growing on a nutrient-rich layer of agar to ultra-violet (UV) radiation. Below a crossover temperature, the bacteria are confined to regions that are shielded from UV radiation. A forced convection of the population is effected by rotating a UV radiation shield relative to the petri dish. The extinction speed at which the bacterial colony lags behind the shield is found to be qualitatively similar to the front velocity of the colony growing in the absence of the hostile environment as predicted by the model of Dahmen, Nelson and Shnerb. A quantitative comparison is not possible without considering the slow dynamics and the time-dependent interaction of the population with the hostile environment.

Bacterial colonies growing on a nutrient rich substrate have served as model systems for studying pattern formation and population dynamics in biological systems. Studies with strains of Bacillus subtilis and Escherichia coli have reported a wide variety of complex patterns depending on nutrient conditions [3, 4, 5, 6]. The patterns have been modeled using reaction-diffusion equations¬†[7, 8, 9]. These experimental and theoretical studies have considered an essentially uniform environment where the changes are due only to the depletion of nutrients with time. However, living organisms often are forced to migrate due to changes in the environment.

The modeling of population dynamics of bacterial colonies due to changes in the environment has been studied recently by Shnerb, Nelson, and Dahmen¬†[10, 11]. Their theoretical model incorporates the effect of a forced convection on the growth of a bacterial colony by considering the convective-diffusion equation given by:

If ùêØ=0ùêØ0ATOM:bold-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\textbf{v}=0 and U‚Å¢(ùê±)ùëàùê±italic-U OPEN:( ATOM:bold-x CLOSE:)U(\textbf{x}) is constant, Eq.¬†(1) corresponds to the Fisher wave equation¬†[12] which has a solution with a limiting constant value of the front speed vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F}. Wakita et al.¬†[13] have studied a colony of Bacillus subtilis in a high nutrient and low agar medium growing in such a Fisher mode.

The two new features of the forced convection model given by Eq.¬†(1) are the introduction of a growth potential U‚Å¢(ùê±)ùëàùê±italic-U OPEN:( ATOM:bold-x CLOSE:)U(\textbf{x}), corresponding to exposing photosensitive bacteria to a light source for example, and the convection of the bacteria due to the motion v of the light source. By considering a colony confined to a rectangular region, the resulting steady-state number density of the bacteria (the time independent solution of Eq.¬†(1)) was obtained in Ref.¬†[11] as a function of v. They concluded that that the total number of bacteria in the rectangular region decreases linearly to zero as vùë£italic-vv approches vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F} from below. The steady-state spatial density distribution was obtained by solving for the time-independent solutions of Eq.¬†(1) numerically. Because the linearized version of Eq.¬†(1) allows a mapping to non-Hermitian quantum mechanics, additional predictions of the properties of bacterial colonies in terms of localization-delocalization transitions in quantum systems can be made¬†[10].

We report the first experimental study of a Bacillus subtilis colony forced to migrate by environmental changes due to a moving ultra-violet (UV) source. UV radiation is shined on a petri dish containing nutrient rich agar except in a rectangular region which is shielded. Although UV radiation is supposed to kill these bacteria¬†[14], we find more subtle behaviors. For example, the colony is confined to the shielded region only when the temperature is below a ‚Äúcrossover‚Äù value of approximately 22‚àòsuperscript22NUMBER:22 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end22^{\circ}C. When the UV radiation is turned off, the front of the colony which was near the boundary between the hostile and favorable regions initially grows slowly, but recovers to the Fisher front speed vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F} in about 25 hours (h). This slow recovery near the boundary suggests the presence of signalling between the bacteria, a feature which is absent in Eq.¬†(1).

To study the effect of a changing environment, we rotate the rectangular shield with a constant angular velocity relative to the petri dish. The bacteria are inoculated along a line inside the rectangular shield region. The rotation results in the colony being forced to convect with velocities that increase linearly from zero at the axis of rotation to a maximum value at the edge of the plate. We find that the bacteria colony cannot keep up with the shielded region if the shield moves with velocities much greater than vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F}, thus showing an extinction transition in qualitative agreement with the theoretical model¬†[11]. The spatial number density n‚Å¢(ùê±,v)ùëõùê±ùë£italic-n OPEN:( bold-x PUNCT:, italic-v CLOSE:)n({\bf x},v) of the bacteria as a function of the speed vùë£italic-vv was measured and found to be time-dependent, even after three days of forced convection. These experimental results illustrate the relevance of Eq.¬†(1) and also indicate that the time-dependent response is of experimental relevance because of the long time scales of biological systems.

We now describe our experimental procedure and observations in more detail. The wild-type strain of Bacillus subtilis was obtained from Presque Isle Cultures and freeze dried at -70‚àòsuperscript70ADDOP:minus NUMBER:70 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end-70^{\circ}C. All experiments were performed from this initial sample by incubating a portion of the sample for 8 h at 30‚àòsuperscript30NUMBER:30 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end30^{\circ}C in nutrient rich broth. A drop of this broth representing a total of at least 107superscript107NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:7 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{7} bacteria is used to inoculate the nutrient rich agar. The experiments were performed in 15‚Äâcm diameter plexiglass petri dishes containing a thin layer of nutrient agar (7‚Äâgrams/liter of bacto-peptone and 3‚Äâgrams/liter agar.) These conditions are similar to that used in previous observations of the Fisher wave mode¬†[13]. When inoculated as a single point source (diameter ‚àºsimilar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 3 mm), the growth of the colony was observed to have a uniform disk shape with a front velocity that increases slowly for the first 8 h and eventually reaches a constant front speed vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F} consistent with previous work¬†[13]. Experiments were performed over a range of temperature (21‚àò-40‚àòsuperscript21superscript40NUMBER:21 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:40 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end21^{\circ}-40^{\circ}C) and it was found that vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F} is an increasing function of temperature within this range with vF=1.7‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢m/ssubscriptùë£ùêπ1.7ùúámsitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.7 italic-mu m MULOP:divide sv_{F}=1.7\,\mu{\rm m/s} at 40‚àòsuperscript40NUMBER:40 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end40^{\circ}C and vF=0.19‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢m/ssubscriptùë£ùêπ0.19ùúámsitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.19 italic-mu m MULOP:divide sv_{F}=0.19\,\mu{\rm m/s} at 21‚àòsuperscript21NUMBER:21 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end21^{\circ}C.

Next we describe our experiments in which we shine UV radiation on the petri dish using two 8‚ÄâW long wavelength UV-lamps placed 5‚Äâcm above the dish. An Aluminum sheet is used to shield a rectangular region of the petri dish from the radiation (see Fig.¬†1). The density of the bacteria is obtained by imaging the light scattered by the bacteria with a CCD camera. Calibration experiments show that the light intensity is proportional to the bacteria density. The colony at time t=23.15ùë°23.15italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:23.15t=23.15‚Äâh after a point inoculation at the center of the petri dish is shown in Fig.¬†1a for 21‚àòsuperscript21NUMBER:21 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end21^{\circ}C. The shielded region is within the dashed lines and has a width w=5ùë§5italic-w RELOP:equals NUMBER:5w=5‚Äâcm. We observe that the front of the colony is circular and its diameter is smaller than wùë§italic-ww. As the colony grows further outward, the edge of the shielded region is reached, and the shape of the colony is no longer circular as shown in Fig.¬†1b. The width of the colony along the axes parallel (xùë•italic-xx) and perpendicular (yùë¶italic-yy) to the shield is plotted in Fig.¬†1c. The error bars correspond to the range of fluctuations due to slightly different initial conditions in different runs. The diameter dùëëitalic-dd of the bacterial colony growing at the same temperature in a petri dish which is completely shielded from UV radiation is also shown. We observe that the colony under the shield grows with a speed comparable to vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F} at that temperature. As the colony approaches the edge of the shield, the front speed slows down because the bacteria are confined.

To further demonstrate that the confinement effect is due to the presence of UV radiation, the UV radiation was turned off after 72 h. We observe no change in the velocity of the front along the xùë•italic-xx-direction as expected, because the bacteria are deep inside the shield. However, we would expect to see a change in the rate of growth along the yùë¶italic-yy-direction because the radiation has been removed. We observe that the front velocity recovers to vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F}, but only after 25 h. This behavior is not modeled by Eq.¬†(1), but is important in our discussion of the convection experiments as discussed below.

We performed experiments at higher temperatures and observed that for temperatures greater than approximately 22‚àòsuperscript22NUMBER:22 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end22^{\circ}C, the bacteria are able to grow into irradiated regions, but with a front speed that decreases with time. (At 26‚àòsuperscript26NUMBER:26 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end26^{\circ}C, the speed was reduced by 41% after 12 h.) Hence, in the presence of radiation we can vary the growth rate by changing the temperature and obtain a transition from a localized colony to one which is delocalized. A detailed study of this phenomena would be an interesting avenue for further research. In this paper we will consider a simple case in which the bacteria are confined at a temperature of 22¬±1‚àòplus-or-minus22superscript1NUMBER:22 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end22\pm 1^{\circ}C to investigate the extinction transition in the presence of convection.

The convection experiments were performed by inoculating the bacteria along a diameter of the petri dish. The petri dish is then kept under a radiation shield of width w=4.3‚Å¢cmùë§4.3cmitalic-w RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.3 cmw=4.3\,{\rm cm} and placed on a rotating platform, similar to the experiments described earlier. As the platform rotates, the region shielded from the UV radiation advances at a speed which increases linearly from the axis of rotation outward. The colony was initially allowed to grow for 14 h before the platform was rotated. During this time the bacteria covered the shielded region. The time t=0ùë°0italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0t=0 corresponds to the time at which the platform was rotated. The results of the colony growth under these conditions are shown in Fig.¬†2. The position of the shielded region and the axis of rotation are indicated. The bacterial population is clearly seen to migrate and follow the shielded region at low velocities near the axis of rotation and lag behind at higher velocities.

These observations are consistent with the theory of Ref.¬†[11] where a phase diagram for the growth and the extinction of a colony as a function of the growth potential Uùëàitalic-UU and the convection speed vùë£italic-vv was obtained using Eq.¬†(1). In particular, it was predicted that the bacteria will be localized to the favorable region. Furthermore, the total bacterial population in favorable regions decreases linearly to zero as a function of vùë£italic-vv as vùë£italic-vv approaches vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F} from below. (In this theory the critical extinction speed vcsubscriptùë£ùëêitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{c} is the same as vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F}.) To make quantitative comparisons, we have extracted the positions of the fronts corresponding to the three images shown in Fig.¬†2. These positions are plotted in Fig.¬†3a; the origin corresponds to the axis of rotation and the initial line of inoculation is along the horizontal axis. The dashed arc in Fig.¬†3a corresponds to the distance where the velocity of the shield is the same as vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F}. We observe that very far from the axis of rotation, the front does not change during the time t=46.56ùë°46.56italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:46.56t=46.56 h to t=73.73ùë°73.73italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:73.73t=73.73 h, indicating that bacteria which could not cope with the speed of the shield were left behind in the hostile irradiated region and did not grow.

Dividing the displacement of the bacteria front by the time difference between images, we extracted the approximate velocity of the front as a function of the radial distance rùëüitalic-rr. Such an analysis ignores the diffusion of the bacteria along the radial direction. The data for the average velocity of the front, vb‚Å¢(r)subscriptùë£ùëèùëüitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:)v_{b}(r), is plotted in Fig.¬†3b. The velocity of the shield v‚Å¢(r)ùë£ùëüitalic-v OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:)v(r) also is plotted to provide a reference for the front velocities. The bacteria are confined to the shielded region, and vb‚Å¢(r)subscriptùë£ùëèùëüitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:)v_{b}(r) is observed to increase with rùëüitalic-rr, but is always less than v‚Å¢(r)ùë£ùëüitalic-v OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:)v(r), the corresponding speed of the shield. The reason for this lag might be due to the slow recovery of the bacteria after the UV irradiated region moves ahead as discussed earlier in reference to Fig.¬†1c. We also observe that vb‚Å¢(r)subscriptùë£ùëèùëüitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:)v_{b}(r) increases linearly up to a velocity of 0.2‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢m/s0.2ùúámsNUMBER:0.2 italic-mu m MULOP:divide s0.2\,\mu{\rm m/s} which corresponds to r‚àº45similar-toùëü45italic-r RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:45r\sim 45‚Äâmm. For greater rùëüitalic-rr, vb‚Å¢(r)subscriptùë£ùëèùëüitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:)v_{b}(r) decreases and the bacteria increasingly lag behind the shield and stop growing for r>80ùëü80italic-r RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:80r>80‚Äâmm. The maximum value of vbsubscriptùë£ùëèitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{b} corresponds to the value of vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F} of the bacteria colony at 22‚àòsuperscript22NUMBER:22 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end22^{\circ}C in the absence of convection and UV radiation.

To explain the velocity data for r>50ùëü50italic-r RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:50r>50‚Äâmm, we note the following. In the interval of time corresponding to the images shown in Figs.¬†2b and 2c, the point where the bacteria completely lag behind the shield decreases from r=75ùëü75italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:75r=75‚Äâmm to r=59ùëü59italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:59r=59‚Äâmm. During this time, the bacteria are exposed to UV radiation for at least part of this time interval which increases for larger rùëüitalic-rr. Hence, because the bacteria grow for only a portion of the total time, the mean front speed vb‚Å¢(r)subscriptùë£ùëèùëüitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:)v_{b}(r) decreases. The front speed is zero when the bacteria are always in the UV radiation corresponding to r>80ùëü80italic-r RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:80r>80‚Äâmm in Fig.¬†3b.

We also note that because of the slow rate of growth of the colony, the relative slow speed of the shield vùë£italic-vv, and the finite width of the shield wùë§italic-ww, a long transient time of the order of w/(v-vc)ùë§ùë£subscriptùë£ùëêitalic-w MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-v ADDOP:minus italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)w/(v-v_{c}) is required for the shield to leave the colony which is growing with a speed vùë£italic-vv less than the critical extinction speed vcsubscriptùë£ùëêitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{c}. This transient time diverges as vùë£italic-vv approaches vcsubscriptùë£ùëêitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{c}. Hence, for an experiment which is conducted over a finite duration, the value of rùëüitalic-rr where the bacteria completely lag behind the shield is larger than the value corresponding to the critical extinction speed vcsubscriptùë£ùëêitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{c}. However, vcsubscriptùë£ùëêitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{c} can be indirectly calculated from the above relation for the transient time. We obtain the estimate vc‚àº0.23‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢m/ssimilar-tosubscriptùë£ùëê0.23ùúámsitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.23 italic-mu m MULOP:divide sv_{c}\sim 0.23\,\mu{\rm m/s} which is similar to the value of vF‚àº0.26similar-tosubscriptùë£ùêπ0.26italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.26v_{F}\sim 0.26 at 22‚àòsuperscript22NUMBER:22 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end22^{\circ}C. This estimate was obtained from the image in Fig.¬†3 using v=0.4‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢m/sùë£0.4ùúámsitalic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.4 italic-mu m MULOP:divide sv=0.4\,\mu{\rm m/s} at r=59ùëü59italic-r RELOP:equals NUMBER:59r=59‚Äâmm where the bacteria have completely lagged behind the shield at time t=73.73‚Å¢hùë°73.73hitalic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:73.73 ht=73.73\,{\rm h} of rotation. Therefore, we find a critical extinction speed consistent with the Fisher wave velocity as predicted in Ref.¬†[11].

A more direct comparison of our experimental results to theory can perhaps be made by considering the time dependent response of the model considered in Eq.¬†(1). Additional considerations such as the time-dependent response of the front speed of the bacteria may have to be incorporated. To encourage future comparisons of experimental data with time-dependent models, we plot the number density n‚Å¢(x,v)ùëõùë•ùë£italic-n OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-v CLOSE:)n(x,v) of the bacteria colony at different distances from the shield in Fig.¬†4 corresponding to different convection velocities vùë£italic-vv. The shielded region normalized by the width wùë§italic-ww corresponds to -0.50.5ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.5-0.5 to 0.5. This data corresponds to the image shown in Fig.¬†2c. These density distributions are still time dependent except at v=0.41‚Å¢Œº‚Å¢m/sùë£0.41ùúámsitalic-v RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.41 italic-mu m MULOP:divide sv=0.41\,\mu{\rm m/s}, which corresponds to distances where the bacteria are immobile because they have been in the UV irradiated regions for a long time. We observe that the front of the colony in the direction of the convection velocity always lags behind the edge of the strip. This characteristic of the bacteria distribution is similar to that predicted in Ref.¬†[11], but a direct comparison is not possible because the distribution is still time-dependent after t=73ùë°73italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:73t=73 h of rotation. From Fig.¬†4 we further observe that the total bacterial population given by the area under the curve decreases for increasing velocity. We have found it impractical to conduct the experiments for a longer time, which is a significant limitation in making a more direct comparison with time-independent predictions.

The fact that the extinction transition occurs near vFsubscriptùë£ùêπitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endv_{F} is an interesting result for real biological systems because of the relatively simple model considered in Refs.¬†[10, 11]. Our experiments are an important first step in investigating the usefulness of convection-diffusion models in studying convection in biological systems. The question remains if the observed evolution of the front can be captured by the time-dependence in Eq.¬†(1) with the same initial conditions or if additional terms which include the time-dependent interactions between the bacteria and the hostile environment are necessary.
